Not that great. The decisions to stop or continue are obvious, so you don’t agonize about your decision nor do you regret it if it doesn’t work out. You just had bad luck.

THE press your luck game. Fun and easy enough for anyone to play. Only potential issue is that splitting/adding the dice can become cumbersome once your options get more limited, but that's a very minor "issue". Only reason my rating isn't higher is because the game isn't very deep and can wear itself thin rather quickly. But it's still a very good time.

Can't Stop might just be one of the most frustrating game I have ever played! The frustration is built in the game itself: you roll 4 dices and must use sets of them to form number from 2 to 12. In our turn you have three rows to put your markers - you decide the rows, but the choice is limited by the numbers rolled, so say you rolled 3, 5, 5 and 6 - you could chose to put your markers in the 8, 9, 10 or 11. Once you put all your three markers, the subsequential rolls will serve only to advance the marker in the said roll. You can roll the dice as many times as you wish, but, if happens that you cannot form a duo of dice that advance one of your markers, you lose all the advance you have made so far in said turn.

So your choices are limited by the dice, but also the choices must be made regarding two things: probability and the advance made by the other players. The rows for 2 and 12 are the smallest ones, and the row for the 7 is the biggest. So roll a 7 is a lot easier, but the game requires many more rolls that add to 7 than those that add to 2, 4, 10, 11 and others. Also, you know that a roll of 6, 7 or 8 is easier to get, but what if your fellow players are already well advanced in all of them? Once a player reaches the end of the row (and ends its turn while the marker is in the topmost position - this is important, as the player can continue to roll and lose the advance that would win the row for him/her) all the advancement made by the others are lost. However, having one of your three markers in the said rows, might grant you more opportunities to get the numbers you really want, as they can "save" your turn (for example, you really want a 4 or a 10, but the dice showed 2, 4, 4 and 5 - if you have a marker in the 6 or the 8 row, you could advance it and continue rolling to get the number you want).

All of this makes for some though choices - when you have them - but also for some really frustrating, well, no-choices. No amount of calculation can save you from the (bad) luck of the roll: the blind luck of someone can win a row, that you couldn't manage to win even after 4 rounds, in a single turn. Making you lose not only the row, but also end your chances there. I have games were I was well posicioned in two rows, and lost both to players that not even started their turns with markers there. In a single round I went from a good position, to having nothing, being behind everyone else in all the other rows. Sure, this can go both ways - I also won rows and games that I wasn't really invested in.

Can't Stop is a short game, but more than once I had no chance to win after the first round - and by "no chance" consider "I just couldn't stop until amazing results happened", which, sometimes, did, but many more times, don't.

I don't say it is a bad game - it isn't. Can't Stop is easy to teach, to play, have some (light) decisions to be made and you can laugh at the greed of your fellow players (and your own). I just found it a little less fun than I thought (I don't see myself playing this over Diamant, for instance - being a game that is also in the type of press your luck, that accommodates up to 8, with much, much less downtime, and the aspect of the fun is the same).

Kinda suprised. It's handled as a classic, and I could see why just from how it's played; it's a very pure and simple push your luck game. It did, however, fail to meet my expectations by quite a bit despite us knowing exactly what it is we are playing (meaning no false assumptions on how much of it is luck and skill, noone expected anything but a fun filler). It felt entirely too long for what it is and I wasn't really engaged or excited about other people's turns. I could play Ra or Port Royal in that time and bith are so much better it's not even funny. The one thing it has going for it is that can't stop is extremely easy, and you could likely deduce all rules by watching 2-3 turns of play. But ease of explanation never was important in my groups. Probably a better experience with the monopoly/munchkin crowd or grandparents, and I don't mean that as an insult.

5 to me means this was 'a game' and I like games as opposed to spending time doing other things. But also some games are nothing more than that. I think Can't Stop is the best example of this kind of game.

Update: Sold; Can get my fix on BGA. Las Vegas is just a better dice game.

The classic push-your-luck game and for good reasons. Intuitive rules, great tension, a bit of tactical decisions, certainly always happy to pull that out with casual gamers for some easy dice-rolling.

Only knocks: The large box which makes carrying it to a gaming event a bit of a challenge and downtime becomes a bit of an issue with 4 players.
A model push-your-luck classic and a sterling example of why Sid Sackson is a giant in game design. Very easy to learn and, at least for the digital implementation on Board Game Arena, quick playing.
I like the wooden pieces in the Eagle-Gryphon edition. The neoprene game mat also makes it very travel friendly.
I'm a sucker for dice gambling. It's good, but best played digitally.

PnP. brilliant, fun and simple push your luck game, ideal as filler and new gamers. Personally would never play with more than 3 players to avoid downtime and it lose steam after a few plays. I have a PnP version that works perfectly

Online plays

One of Sid Sackson’s best games, and a perfect example of push your luck done well. The illusion of probability always tells the player it’s safe to roll again… you can’t stop

The game can drag, and the more balanced the game is, the longer it will be because more possibilities are being removed, meaning you are more likely to bust on your first few rolls
Dice are just so satisfying to roll. Nevertheless, I tend to prefer Cards to Dice (in board games). Can't Stop makes dice feel right, where other games make dice feel wrong.

I love how quickly the rules disappear. Within minutes, the game becomes gasps, groans and laughter. It’s fast and full of energy. The fun doesn’t come from design gimmicks or intricate systems, but from the simple, universal tension between greed and risk taking. You chase numbers, you tempt fate, you cheer and curse.

What’s brilliant is how Can’t Stop creates all this emotion with almost nothing. Just four dice, a couple of markers and the heartbeat of risk and reward. It reminds me of what games used to be, namely social, immediate and joyful.

Push your luck at its simplest and best. I introduced this game to my kids at 5 and 3 years old and it worked great. It's a go-to game for my wife and I to play and it's just plain great for what it is. Works with gamers, non-gamers, friends, neighbors, family, everyone.

Sid Sackson rules!
Check out "Rule of 28" if you want to become better at Can't Stop.

Une édition au top pour un grand classique. Une sorte d'hommage rendu à ce grand ancien indétrônable, jeu de stop ou encore et de course au sommet. Les bonzes ont été remplacés par des tentes et des petits piolets. Le boitage est fabuleux. Produit d'importation (de Corée), ce jeu revient cher mais il fera sans aucun doute office de cadeau de qualité.

2025: made my own travel copy out of spare parts from other games. Small and easy to pack, now one of my go tos for traveling.

2014: Heard this was a classic, and the people weren't wrong!! Super fun! Just enough control to feel like you have control, and enough dice rolling to make it dramatic and keep the skill ceiling low. Love it!
An amazing push your luck game that will always make you say, “Can’t stop won’t stop!!”. Great for opening up to get people ready for an amazing game night that will get them excited and motivated.
Stop? … Can’t stop.

This is a 9 for me right now because of how good the implementation on BGA is - quick to pick up a game, no friction to playing. I think playing in person would drop it down very quickly to more like a 6 or 7. The push your luck is fun and addictive when it's quick, but with in person decision making pushing the game length to more like 30 minutes instead of 8, I doubt I would find it as fun

Board game

So simple and pure in it's mechanics, but so fun and engaging.

10 is for the old Ravensburger edition with the plastic board. Newer editions would probably get an 8

The push-your-luck game, I suppose. There's not much to the game, but it's still extraordinarily fun. You can play the odds as much as you want, but sure-things don't exist. Giant clunky stop sign board is awesome.

It's kind of clever how filling up the board can help trailing players catch up. But when the board gets too full, it swings back to dangerous. How many boardgames even have an arc? Some players will overdo the probability calculations, then hilariously bust anyway.

The most amazing session of this I ever had was after a few columns had been claimed, someone with 0 points said they had to go anyway, but they'll do 1 more turn just to see what happens. They became unstoppable, climbing and getting 3 points in one turn, winning instantly. Not many games even come close to that.
Always willing for a game. Perfect filler push your luck game. Can't stop!

I consider this game nearly perfectly designed for what it aims to do. In particular, I love that if four players manage to get two columns completed each, there are 3 numbers left, so everyone's turn becomes just as if you chose those three numbers during your turn.

This was bought in a group of 6 from GeekMarket. I had to average each game out from the total.

Averaged Cost: $21.10
Can't Stop is a classic that I prefer at two or three players. With four the down time is too much.
Fun game to throw dice around.
